articles.headline: Severe Report Finds V.A. Hid Waiting Lists at Hospitals
articles.snippet: The Department of Veterans Affairs reported Wednesday that at least 1,700 veterans at a medical center in Phoenix were not registered on the proper waiting list, putting them at risk in the scheduling process.
articles.abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs reported Wednesday that at least 1,700 veterans at a medical center in Phoenix were not registered on the proper waiting list, putting them at risk in the scheduling process.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the first confirmation that Department of Veterans Affairs administrators manipulated medical waiting lists at one and possibly more hospitals, the department’s inspector general reported on Wednesday that 1,700 patients at the veterans medical center in Phoenix were not placed on the official waiting list for doctors’ appointments and may never have received care.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Apple to Pay $3 Billion to Buy Beats
articles.snippet: In a move that will help Apple play catch-up with rivals that offer subscription-based music services, the company will offer both Beats’s streaming music service and its premium headphones.
articles.abstract: In a move that will help Apple play catch-up with rivals that offer subscription-based music services, the company will offer both Beats’s streaming music service and its premium headphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple, the company that turned digital music into a mainstream phenomenon, said on Wednesday that it was buying Beats Electronics, a rising music brand, for $3 billion, in a move that will help it play catch-up with rivals that offer subscription-based music services.

articles.headline: The Soylent Revolution Will Not Be Pleasurable
articles.snippet: A powdered product that purports to obviate the need for eating traditional meals may offer nourishment, but does not deliver any of food’s joys.
articles.abstract: A powdered product that purports to obviate the need for eating traditional meals may offer nourishment, but does not deliver any of food’s joys.
articles.lead_paragraph: I just spent more than a week experiencing Soylent, the most joyless new technology to hit the world since we first laid eyes on MS-DOS.

articles.headline: ‘Upset’ G.M. Engineer Spoke in House Inquiry
articles.snippet: Raymond DeGiorgio, who was suspended last month with pay, has not spoken publicly since General Motors acknowledged an ignition switch defect in February.
articles.abstract: Raymond DeGiorgio, who was suspended last month with pay, has not spoken publicly since General Motors acknowledged an ignition switch defect in February.
articles.lead_paragraph: An engineer at General Motors who is at the center of accusations that the company covered up a deadly defect appeared distraught during lengthy questioning by congressional investigators, according to people familiar with the session.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Santander Bank to Face Suit Claiming Bias in Mortgages
articles.snippet: The lawsuit will claim that between 2009 and 2012, the number of new mortgages in minority neighborhoods of Providence, R.I., fell 63 percent.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit will claim that between 2009 and 2012, the number of new mortgages in minority neighborhoods of Providence, R.I., fell 63 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the housing bubble expanded in the early 2000s, mortgage lenders aggressively handed out money in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, though often at exorbitant rates and in ways that made the loans unaffordable to more vulnerable borrowers. Now, the pendulum has swung the other way, raising concerns that some banks are shutting out blacks and Hispanics in favor of white homeowners.

articles.headline: A Pushback on Green Power
articles.snippet: Opponents of government policies that have spurred the growth of renewable energy are pushing back on mandates nationwide.
articles.abstract: Opponents of government policies that have spurred the growth of renewable energy are pushing back on mandates nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: As renewable energy production has surged in recent years, opponents of government policies that have helped spur its growth have pushed to roll back those incentives and mandates in state after state.

articles.headline: Jimmy Iovine, a Master of Beats, Lends Apple a Skilled Ear
articles.snippet: Apple is betting that Mr. Iovine’s four decades in the recording industry, his knack for trend-spotting and his credibility with artists will help rejuvenate its music business.
articles.abstract: Apple is betting that Mr. Iovine’s four decades in the recording industry, his knack for trend-spotting and his credibility with artists will help rejuvenate its music business.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple’s new music impresario, Jimmy Iovine, didn’t start out writing code or studying computer engineering, the usual path of a Silicon Valley mogul. Instead, his career began sweeping floors at New York City recording studios and fetching tea for John Lennon.

articles.headline: Terror’s Front: Local Groups, Eyes on West
articles.snippet: Decentralized Qaeda affiliates and extremists now pose “the most direct threat” to the United States and American interests abroad, the president said Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Decentralized Qaeda affiliates and extremists now pose “the most direct threat” to the United States and American interests abroad, the president said Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Benghazi militant group Ansar al-Shariah is under attack by a renegade former general trying to rid Libya of political Islam. But in response, the militia has taken aim squarely at Washington.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Ackman Said to Plan Public Hedge Fund in London
articles.snippet: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management plans to raise money for a closed-end fund that could list on the London Stock Exchange
articles.abstract: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management plans to raise money for a closed-end fund that could list on the London Stock Exchange
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Wall Street’s boldest investors, the billionaire hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, is building an unusual multibillion-dollar war chest.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Contracted in a Frigid First Quarter
articles.snippet: The economy contracted at an annual rate of 1 percent earlier this year, the first quarterly decline in three years.
articles.abstract: The economy contracted at an annual rate of 1 percent earlier this year, the first quarterly decline in three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was an economic quarter no one wants to repeat.

articles.headline: Bias Claims for Insurers in Coverage of H.I.V.
articles.snippet: Two health care advocacy groups filed a complaint against CoventryOne, Cigna, Humana and Preferred Medical Plan for what they said was discrimination in Florida.
articles.abstract: Two health care advocacy groups filed a complaint against CoventryOne, Cigna, Humana and Preferred Medical Plan for what they said was discrimination in Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: Health care advocates said on Thursday that four insurers offering plans in the new federal marketplace discriminated against people with H.I.V. or AIDS by requiring them to pay high out-of-pocket costs for drugs to treat H.I.V., including generic medications.
